Expectation1: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation1: A mandatory pre-shift briefing on new operational procedures is about to start.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story: I sat in the break room, uniform crisp, cap in hand, waiting for the supervisor to begin the pre-shift briefing. The new operational procedures were strict, and missing the session would mean risking a reprimand or worse. My phone buzzed quietly in my pocket—a message from Sister Agnes. A parishioner, Maria, was waiting in the chapel, desperate to talk. She was in the midst of a crisis of faith, and as a nun, I was expected to offer guidance, to listen, to be present for her spiritual needs. My heart ached, torn between the duty to my passengers and the sacred responsibility to my community. The clock ticked closer to the briefing. I could picture Maria’s anxious face, her hope that I might help her find peace. At the same time, I knew the subway couldn’t run safely without operators who understood the new protocols. The weight of both uniforms pressed on me, and I sat frozen, caught between the rails and the rosary, unsure which path to follow.
